text: I open the ledger and look up. “Are you booking a room for Lucia as well?”
“Yes. She’ll be helping me sort medicinal herbs tonight.”
“The room next door is quiet. The wind isn’t too strong there.” I say, handing over two keys.
As she takes the keys, her gaze lingers briefly on my fingertips, her expression gentle and strangely unreadable.
“Master! I’ll go tidy up!”
“Don’t touch the windowsill!”
Lucia runs upstairs cheerfully with her basket of herbs, her footsteps light as wind chimes. Alicia watches her retreating figure and lets out a soft sigh.
“Your apprentice is quite adorable.”
“She’s a good child. Much luckier than I was. I found her in a war-torn village. She was only ten at the time.”
Her voice lowers slightly, as if afraid of disturbing some long-sealed memory.
“Back then… her family?”
“They were all gone.” She pauses, gently rubbing the key between her fingers. “When I found her, she was clutching a broken lamp, still waiting for someone.”
The hearthlight reflects faintly off her armor. The room grows so quiet that only the crackle of firewood remains.
“Since then, she’s stayed with me. She mixes herbs, memorizes roads, asks countless questions… just like she does now.”
“You see her as family, don’t you?”
“Perhaps.” She offers the faintest smile. “But sometimes I think she understands how to live better than I do.”
For a moment, I have no words. I can only watch the firelight flicker in her eyes. The smile is subtle, yet beneath it lies a sorrow that is hard to notice.
“I should get some rest.”
“The air feels damp today. It’ll probably snow again tonight.”
“I’ll save dinner for you both.”
“Thank you.”
“I can’t help feeling that this place gives me a strange sense of déjà vu.”
Her footsteps upstairs are incredibly light, almost silent.
I watch her back as she leaves, feeling an inexplicable tightness in my chest.
I lower my gaze and see the brass die resting quietly on the counter.
The wind brushes past the eaves, carrying the distant toll of the church bells.
At that moment, I suddenly feel as though time itself is gently swaying, as if someone behind the scenes has lightly turned a hidden gear.
